Basic Data Structures¶

Coding examples for basic data structures.

  • arrays
  • stacks
  • queues
  • deques
class data_structures.DynamicArray → array[source]¶

Python implementation of an array, where existing capacity is doubled when new space is required.

This demonstrates the advantages of amortization of costs over the life of a function.

While the cost of doubling the array is expensive it is far less expensive than adding one cell over time.

>>> d = data_structures.DynamicArray()
>>> d.items
0
>>> d.capacity
1
>>> d.append('one')
>>> d.items
1
>>> d.capacity
1
>>> d.append('two')
>>> d.items
2
>>> d.capacity
2
>>> foo = [d.append(x) for x in range(16)]
>>> d.items
18
>>> d.capacity
32
append(value)[source]¶
class data_structures.ListDeque → deque[source]¶

Implement a deque - Using python lists.

>>> q = data_structures.ListDeque()
>>> q.is_empty()
True
>>> for i in range(4): q.push(i)
>>> for i in range(4): q.lpush(i)
>>> for i in range(2): print(q.lpop())
3
2
>>> for i in range(5): print(q.pop())
3
2
1
0
0
is_empty() → bool[source]¶
lpop() → item Left[source]¶

pop() → item Right[source]¶

size() → int[source]¶
class data_structures.ListQueue → queue[source]¶

Implement a queue - Using python lists

>>> q = data_structures.ListQueue()
>>> for i in range(5): q.push(i)
>>> for i in range(5): print q.pop()
0
1
2
3
4

class data_structures.ListStack → stack[source]¶

Implement a stack - Using python lists

>>> q = data_structures.ListStack()
>>> for i in range(5): q.push(i)
>>> for i in range(5): print q.pop()

3
2
1
0

class data_structures.Queue2Stacks → stack[source]¶

Implement a queue - Using two stacks (python lists)

>>> q = data_structures.Queue2Stacks()
>>> for i in range(5): q.push(i)
>>> for i in range(5): print q.pop()
0
1
2
3
4
